title: Itaú Chile
description: In 2022, Itaú—the largest bank in Latin America—launched Itu, its first fully digital B2C product in Chile. The product was built on a clear differentiation strategy grounded in three simple pillars, deeply connected to insights from research with Chilean consumers: everyday simplicity, transparency that builds trust, and education that empowers financial autonomy.

A key part of this strategy is Chanchitus—digital money spaces that allow customers to separate and organize funds for different goals. More than following a trend among digital banks, Chanchitus respond to a common local behavior of using multiple banks to segment money, enabling customers to manage their finances within a single app while maintaining a unified financial view.

title: Deutsche Telekom
description: In 2023, Deutsche Telekom partnered with Work & Co to redefine its digital experience and brand expression. As part of this program, one initiative focused on reimagining the future of TV and shaping Deutsche Telekom’s strategic direction in the segment.

The work resulted in nearly 50 concepts outlining a vision for a hyper-personalized, context-aware, multi-channel TV experience powered by AI. Several concepts addressed the declining relevance of traditional live TV by enhancing on-demand viewing through smarter content curation and adaptation to individual viewing behaviors—such as breaking movies into shorter episodes or assembling personalized on-demand schedules from live content.

At the same time, the concepts strengthened live experiences where they still matter most, with sports as a key focus. Ideas included personalized sports timelines, enhanced key moments, and live social interaction layers. Together, concepts around personalization, intent recognition, and second-screen interaction connected live and on-demand viewing, outlining a near future where TV is intelligent, adaptive, and deeply personal.

title: Vivo Casa Inteligente
description: In 2022, Vivo—part of the Telefónica group and the largest telecommunications company in Brazil—began repositioning to expand beyond traditional telecom services into technology solutions, including smart home and residential automation.

In Brazil, smart home solutions remain a niche category, and adoption is mainly limited by perceived complexity among mass-market customers, rather than price. To address this, Vivo leveraged its nationwide workforce to offer in-home consulting and installation. Reducing friction not only in adoption but also in daily use, the Vivo Casa Inteligente app was designed as a simple control layer, validated through usability testing with Vivo’s target audience, and tailored to be more accessible for this segment than tools such as Google Home, Amazon Alexa, or Smart Life. The app combines device control, integrated support, and lightweight educational content.

To build awareness at scale, an educational experience was also added to Vivo’s main app. It explains the smart home offering and allows customers to explore it through a guided virtual tour, helping a broad audience understand the value of connected-home solutions before adoption.
